In the past two decades, fully data-driven (empirical) models have emerged with the breakthroughs of novel deep learning methods in runoff prediction. These breakthroughs were favored by the large volume, variety, and velocity of water-related data. Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) neural networks have achieved the milestone of outperforming classic hydrological models in less than a decade. They have the potential to change the way hydrological modeling is performed.

This study used precipitation, minimum and maximum temperature at the Ansongo-Niamey basin, combined with discharge at Ansongo and Kandadji, to predict discharge at Niamey using artificial neural networks. After data preprocessing and hyperparameter optimization, the deep learning models performed well, with LSTM and GRU scoring a Nash-Sutcliffe Efficiency of 0.933 and 0.935, respectively. This performance matches that of well-known physically-based models used to simulate Niamey's discharge, demonstrating the efficiency of deep learning methods in a West African context, particularly in Niamey, which has been facing severe floods due to climate change.

Keywords: Ansongo-Niamey basin, deep learning, gated recurrent unit, hydrological model, hyperparameter optimization, long short-term memory

1 Introduction

The Niger Basin, particularly the Middle Niger Basin, has experienced extensive catastrophic flooding over the last two decades, with a high frequency and large extent in the city of Niamey. To alleviate the suffering of the population, improving hydrological models could be a possible mitigation solution by enhancing early warning systems. Many hydrological models have been deployed to predict discharge in Niamey, including physically-based models such as Niger-HYdrological Predictions for the Environment (Niger-HYPE), Interaction between Soil Biosphere and Atmosphere-Total Runoff Integrating Pathway (ISBA-TRIP), Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT), and HydroGeoSphere (HGS). However, few hydrological models have performed well in Niamey at discharge prediction.

Artificial intelligence (AI) based models, which are fully data-driven, appear to be able to overcome the deficiencies of physically-based hydrological models. In hydrology, deep learning (DL) is a subset of machine learning well-known for predicting and estimating floods, monitoring droughts accurately, analyzing atmospheric imaging, estimating tropical cyclones and their precursors, and predicting other hydrological processes.

The Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network, proposed by Hochreiter and Schmidhuber (1997), is an innovative DL method for achieving high accuracy time series prediction and reducing CPU cost. The Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) is an improved version of the LSTM, proposed by Chung et al. (2014), and is able to outperform its predecessor. Shen (2018) demonstrates that DL can help address several major new and old challenges facing research in water science, and hydrological modeling is no exception.

This study aims to find alternative hydrological models to better face climate change damages by simulating efficiently the Niger river discharge in the city of Niamey using artificial neural networks. The methodology includes (i) preprocessing climate and hydrological data, (ii) optimizing LSTM and GRU hyperparameters, and (iii) training and testing the DL models.

2 Study Area

The Ansongo-Niamey basin is a transborder catchment located in the middle region of the Niger basin between Burkina Faso, Mali, and Niger. Ansongo (Mali) is the outlet of the upper Niger basin and was considered the upstream of this study area. The Ansongo-Niamey basin was chosen as the study area because it would be challenging to collect data from the upper Niger basin. The basin's runoff regime is affected by recurring floods, which flow from different geographic locations with distinct characteristics. The first flood is the annual peak during the rainy season (July to November) in the Ansongo-Niamey basin, known as the "Red Flood".
